sentence.idiomatic: They are not that powerful. We can just pick someone to go rough them up and we'll win.
I've heard that the other party is a negotiations expert. You had better be careful when you're facing off with him.
Mother and daughter-in-law are at each other's throats. I'm stuck in the middle and can't do a thing.
You are able to translate Tang poetry so exquisitely. You are really a translating ace.
We have a lot of experts in our company. I can learn a lot from them.
You're facing off with a Latin dance expert. You had better step up your practicing.
Don't rush. Take aim and then shoot at the basket.
Your aim is so good--you get almost every shot.
When doing business you need to target the market requirements--supply what the market demands.
What kind of friends are you? Not only do you not help, you stand there making sarcastic comments.
Don't pay any attention to other's sarcastic remarks. We just have to do what's right ourselves and that's good enough.
I can't stand those kinds of people who stand by and make irresponsible comments when others run into difficulties.
Don't tilt this box when you are moving it.
After he had children, he gradually shifted his attention towards family.
When doing this movement, the body must be tilted forward at a 45 degree angle.
Woah! Look what the wind blew in, if it isn't Manager Li.
Quit babbling. Pick up your cue and let's get down to it.
All right. I haven't played billiards in quite some time, especially with such a shark.
I'll rack, you break.
Let me chalk up first.
Oh, nice positioning of the cue ball off the break. Your skills have gotten better.
No, no. I'm still in the process of learning... I just pocketed a solid.
OK, then I am stripes.
Hey pretty nice. A shark is a shark, your aim on the corner pocket is really accurate.
My turn. Oh no, how did I scratch the cue ball?
Oh, it is definitely a problem with the table, it could be tilted a bit...
Enough! Quit going on with your talk. It's your ball.
OK, OK, OK.
